title: Causal Inference in Ad Effectivenes: Moving Beyond Correlation to True Impact
author: PRL Insights Team
summary:
Measuring advertising effectiveness has always been a challenge. Marketers want to know not just whether ads are associated with outcomes like conversions, sign-ups, or sales — but whether those ads caused the outcome.

This distinction between correlation and causation is at the heart of modern ad measurement. With platforms like Meta (Facebook and Instagram), advertisers run complex campaigns across multiple channels and formats, making it difficult to disentangle the true drivers of impact. This is where causal inference modeling comes in.
content:
Why Causal Inference

Traditional attribution models (first-touch, last-touch, even advanced rule-based or probabilistic models like Markov Chains) often answer the question: What paths do users take before conversion?

But they rarely answer: What would have happened if we had not shown the ad at all?

That counterfactual question — what if things had gone differently? — is the essence of causal inference. Without it, advertisers risk over-crediting channels that are merely correlated with conversions rather than truly driving them.

Key Causal Inference Approaches in Ad Effectiveness

Randomized Controlled Experiments (Gold Standard)

Meta has built-in tools like Conversion Lift Studies that randomly assign audiences into treatment (exposed) and control (unexposed) groups. By comparing outcomes between groups, you estimate the incremental lift attributable to the campaign.

Strength: Cleanest measure of causality

Limitation: Costly, sometimes infeasible for small advertisers or across multiple platforms.

Quasi-Experimental Designs

When randomized experiments aren’t possible, causal inference techniques approximate them using observational data.

  • Difference-in-Differences (DiD): Compare exposed vs. unexposed groups before and after campaign launch.
  • Propensity Score Matching (PSM): Match ad-exposed users with similar unexposed users based on demographics, behaviors, and past activity.
  • Synthetic Control: Construct a “synthetic” comparison group by weighting multiple control groups to mimic the treatment group.

These methods help reduce bias and isolate the ad’s causal effect.

Causal Machine Learning

Newer methods leverage machine learning for high-dimensional data and complex treatment effects:

  • Double Machine Learning (DML): Separates outcomes prediction and treatment assignment to correct for bias.
  • Causal Forests / Uplift Modeling: Estimate heterogeneous treatment effects, i.e., which segments of customers respond most to ads.
  • Bayesian Structural Time Series (BSTS): Model counterfactual trends to estimate the incremental effect of a campaign.

These tools go beyond average lift, revealing nuanced insights like which channels drive incremental conversions and which audiences are most persuadable.

Applying Causal Inference for Meta Advertisers

For brands advertising on Meta Platforms, causal inference can answer pressing questions such as:

  • What is the true incremental sales lift from Instagram Stories vs. Facebook Feed ads?
  • Does combining Meta campaigns with YouTube or Connected TV amplify results, or just duplicate reach?
  • Which creative strategy (video vs. static, short vs. long) drives incremental conversion lift across audience segments?

By applying these methods, advertisers move beyond descriptive reporting and toward causal insights that inform smarter budget allocation.

The Cross-Media Challenge

Modern marketing isn’t siloed. A consumer might see a Meta ad, a YouTube video, and a display banner before converting. Without causal methods, it’s nearly impossible to determine the relative contribution of each platform.

Advanced causal inference — especially when paired with experimental design and identity-resolution techniques — allows advertisers to estimate not just Meta’s standalone impact, but also how it interacts with TV, search, and other digital media.

This is critical for marketing mix optimization: knowing whether shifting dollars from one channel to another actually increases total conversions rather than just shifting attribution.

Final Thoughts

Causal inference represents the next frontier of ad effectiveness measurement. While correlation-based attribution models like Markov chains help map the customer journey, causal inference goes a step further — quantifying the true incremental impact of advertising strategies.

For Meta advertisers, adopting these methods means moving from surface-level metrics (clicks, impressions) to scientifically validated insights about what actually drives business growth.

In an era of rising privacy restrictions, fragmented media, and tighter budgets, the ability to measure causal impact across channels is not just a nice-to-have — it’s a competitive advantage.

title: Why Marketing Mix Modeling is gaining traction in this multi-touch attribution world
author: PRL Insights Team
summary: When it comes to advertising budget, there is a famous quote:. 'Half the money I spend on advertising is wasted; the trouble is, I don’t know which half.' — John Wanamaker
content:
We have been having issues from the past in terms of how we attribute the actual impact of each advertising channel based on the budgets we are running, we have been faced with many challenges.

At this moment, there are top schools of thought to bring data-driven decision-making to optimize on advertising budget. The famous one includes marketing mix modeling (MMM) based on a top-down approach and the other is multi-touch attribution (MTA) based on a bottom-up approach.

Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM): The Top-Down Approach

Marketing mix modeling (MMM) is often considered a top-down approach because it involves analyzing historical data and macro-level factors to determine the optimal allocation of marketing resources across various channels.

Aggregating data analysis: MMM typically begins by historical sales data, marketing spending, and other relevant variables at an aggregate level. This involves looking at overall trends and patterns rather than individual customer behavior or campaign performance.

Macro-Level Factors: MMM takes into account broader market factors such as economic conditions, seasonality, competitive activity, and industry trends. These macro-level factors help in understanding how external forces impact marketing effectiveness and overall business performance.

Allocation of Resources: Based on the analysis of historical data and macro-level factors, MMM helps in determining the optimal allocation of marketing resources across different channels (e.g., TV advertising, digital marketing, and print media). It identifies which marketing activities contribute most effectively to sales and profitability, guiding decisions on budget allocation.

Modeling and Simulation: MMM involves building statistical models to simulate the impact of changes in marketing variables (such as ad spend, pricing, and promotions) on sales or other key performance metrics. These models provide insights into how adjustments to the marketing mix can optimize outcomes, allowing for scenario planning and budget optimization.

Cross-Channel Optimization: MMM considers the interplay between different marketing channels and activities to identify synergies and trade-offs. It helps in understanding how changes in one channel affect the performance of others, enabling marketers to optimize the overall marketing mix for maximum impact.

Overall, marketing mix modeling provides a high-level view of marketing effectiveness and resource allocation, making it a top-down approach that guides strategic decision-making at the organizational level.

Multi-Touch Attribution (MTA): The Bottom-Up Approach

Let’s talk about MTA now.

Multi-touch attribution (MTA) is often considered a bottom-up approach because it focuses on analyzing individual customer interactions and touchpoints to understand their contribution to conversions or sales. Here’s how MTA fits into the bottom-up framework:

Granular Data Analysis: MTA relies on granular data at the individual customer level, including interactions across various marketing channels and touchpoints. It tracks customer journeys from initial awareness to final conversion, providing detailed insights into the effectiveness of each touchpoint along the way.

Customer-Centric Perspective: MTA takes a customer-centric perspective, focusing on understanding the specific paths that customers take before making a purchase decision. It attributes value to each touchpoint based on its influence on the customer journey, rather than looking at aggregate trends or macro-level factors.

Attribution Modeling: MTA involves building attribution models that assign credit to different touchpoints based on their role in driving conversions. These models can be based on various methodologies, such as linear attribution, time decay, or algorithmic models that assign different weights to different touchpoints based on their impact.

Data Integration: MTA integrates data from multiple sources, including marketing platforms, CRM systems, and other customer touchpoints. By aggregating and analyzing data from various sources, it provides a holistic view of the customer journey and helps in understanding how different touchpoints interact with each other.

Optimization at the Tactical Level: MTA enables marketers to optimize their marketing efforts at a tactical level by identifying which touchpoints are most effective in driving conversions. It allows for testing and refining marketing strategies based on insights gained from individual customer interactions, leading to more targeted and efficient campaigns.

Overall, multi-touch attribution provides a bottom-up perspective on marketing effectiveness by analyzing individual customer interactions and touchpoints, allowing marketers to make data-driven decisions at a granular level to optimize their strategies and improve ROI.

title: Essential considerations for digital marketers to implement leading marketing analytics practices through incrementality testing
author: PRL Insights Team
summary: As soon as you walk into the marketing analytics department, you are sure to hear these buzz words like A/B testing, test/control group, sample size evaluation, treatment group etc.– by the way, all these concepts that are derived from statistics and sample theories, are not just nerds talking but business leaders wants to know whether we are really applying these concepts in improving the performance of our marketing
content:
There is no denying that split testing provides actionable insights based on causal inferences, and debunks the correlation present through either interpretation or data. It is also a great tool for marketers to test out different experiment results in real-time to make important decisions on media planning.

“We constantly test theories and ideas before scaling them to ensure maximum impact. Over 20–30% of every campaign budget is reserved by Google for Testing” — Google

However, in recent years, we have been navigating through rough waters, in post-cookie, privacy-safe world, product line changes made by big advertising platforms, announcement by Apple on iOS 14.5 updates on giving more control to user on what should be tracked through their devices. No doubt, it has created a tough environment for marketers to test out on their impact on advertising.

Despite these challenges, we still need to carry out experiments on:

  • What target audiences are better for driving success metrics?
  • How platform advertising bidding strategies should work to optimize on media buying?
  • What ad creatives might be working or which media channel?

Based on different marketing objectives, we can have quantifiable test setups to track marketing goals, such as website traffic, acquiring new accounts, sign-ups, subscriptions, online purchases, return on ad spend or in online-to-offline sales.

But, if businesses want to establish best-in-class analytics practices. They should be able to identify what type of incrementality tests should be setup to finding solutions.

Audience Based Incrementality Tests

The fundamental focus is on type of users that are divided into randomize treatment and control groups to measure incremental impact of marketing efforts on their behavior. Again, the focus is on measuring the causal efforts of the marketing activities.

Audience focused tests drives personalized targeting and messaging strategies.

Many of the brand lift and conversion lift studies that are run on online video ads and display advertising are based on audience based incrementality testing. One caveat for these types of experiment is called selection bias that occurs when test sample sizes are smaller. This is due to the fact that understanding behavioral changes from your ads based on user actions requires larger sample sizes to detect statistically significant differences. If sample sizes are not large enough, tests results may not reach at high confidence level to conclude any significant differences.

Other types of experimentation that can be carried through audience based randomized experiments relates ad copy variations or creative changes that might occur in campaigns or video ads. The setup remains the same, but these types of tests may not require larger samples sizes as do brand or conversion lift studies.

Location Based Incrementality Tests

This is one of my favorite, location-based incrementality tests or often referred to as geo-testing, is a method used to measure the incremental impact of marketing activities by manipulating media delivery in specific geographic regions. The usefulness of this experimentation is that its privacy-safe as it uses aggregated, market-level data rather than user-level data, making it resilient to signal loss and privacy regulations. [Geo-Experimentations]

Setting up the test is not difficult, as a marketer, based on historical data evaluation, it requires a good understanding of how to select test and control regions, measuring the right set of success metrics, and estimating the control scenarios.

As mentioned, the benefits of location based incrementality test out-weighs its limitations. In a privacy safe world, this type of experiment provides a true incremental value of marketing spend. Some challenges include trying to avoid seasonal variation impacts, tent-pole events, other marketing activities running con-currently at local or national level etc.

Google Research has come up with its own experimentation design on geo-experiments, please read the research paper on “Measuring ad effectiveness using geo experiments”.

Time-bound Incrementality Tests

If you are evaluating overall results for your site face-lift, comparing quality of specific site content, and measuring the effectiveness of promotional content or customer satisfaction ratings, then time-bound incrementality tests are the best methodology for understanding your success metrics.

Essentially, time-bound incrementality tests (often referred to as pre-post analysis) is a research method used to measure the impact of an intervention by comparing data collected before (pre) and after (post) the intervention.

Most common statistical analysis tests that are used to set experiments include: T-Test, ANOVA/ANCOVA or linear mixed models, each having its own benefits.

However, setting up an experiment is challenging due to biases such as external factors like seasonality, competitor actions, or other concurrent changes etc.

Pre-post analysis experimentation is a valuable tool for measuring the impact of interventions across various fields. By carefully designing the experiment and choosing the appropriate statistical methods, researchers can obtain reliable and actionable insights into the effectiveness of their interventions.

Let me know what other incrementality tests are present in the market, that are useful to measure performance of your marketing efforts? Please comment below.
